sentence: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is set to report third quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.
The main story here will be the potential long-term effect of last week’s completed spinoff and merger of its software business with Micro Focus.
HPE stock closed Friday at $14.31, almost 21% below Thursday’s close of $18.06.
The decline in share price, which is the result of the spinoff and, in particular, CEO Meg Whitman's ongoing initiatives to slim down HPE and make it more nimble, was not a surprise.
“HPE has achieved a major milestone in becoming a stronger, more focused company, purpose-built to compete and win in today’s market,” Whitman, said in a news release Friday.

“And, this transaction will deliver approximately $8.8 billion to HPE and its stockholders.”

The deal with Micro Focus, which included an $2.5 billion upfront cash payment to HPE, was first announced in September 2016.
With the merger now completed, HPE will retain 50.1% ownership of the combined company Micro Focus International PLC.
At the same time, closing the deal opens an old wound with Britain-based Autonomy, which HPE bought for $11 billion then infamously took an $8.8 billion writedown on a few years later.

On Tuesday investors will want to know the extent to which this spinoff elevates HPE’s enterprise postponing when compared to cloud players such as Amazon (AMZN), Salesforce.com (CRM) and Microsoft (MSFT).

As it stands, despite similar maneuvering aimed at making the company more cloud relevant, HPE stock — up just 6% this year and 10% in twelve months — has underperformed the S&P 500 index in both spans.
And it certainly hasn’t helped that HPE has missed the Street’s revenue estimates in the past four quarters, while suffering a double-digit revenue declines in the past two.
For the quarter that ended July, Wall Street expect HPE to report EPS of 26 cents, down from 49 cents, while revenue of the $7.49 billion would decline 38.6% year over year.
For the full year, ending October, earnings are projected to decline from $1.92 per share to $1.44 per share, while revenue of $33.08 billion would mark a 34% decline year over year.
The projected declines for the top and bottom lines are the result of the company’s separation from its printing arm, Hewlett Inc. (HPQ).
HPE’s focus on hardware for data centers instead of faster-growing software has posed a challenge.

Whitman, who remains confident that HPE continues to head in the right direction, will do her best Tuesday to assure investors that revenue not only can stabilize, but HPE can win the type of cloud deals that has restored analysts’ confidence in competitors likes Oracle (ORCL).
To that end, investors may lose patience in Whitman’s assurances, unless the company guides confidently for the current quarter and full year.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
